plausible_answers.text: flatter, lighter motifs, sculpted in low frieze-like relief or painted in monotones en camaïeu ("like cameos"),

qas.question: What techniques were excluded from the style?
What was initially a Parisien style in Greece?
What we brought the Gout grec style to court?

context: The new interiors sought to recreate an <a0_0><b5_0>authentically Roman<a0_0/> and genuinely interior vocabulary<b5_0/>. Techniques employed in the style included <a3_0><b6_0>flatter, lighter motifs, sculpted in low frieze-like relief or painted in monotones<a3_0/> en camaïeu ("like cameos"),<b6_0/> isolated medallions or vases or busts or bucrania or other motifs, suspended on swags of laurel or ribbon, with slender arabesques against backgrounds, perhaps, of <a1_0>"Pompeiian red" or pale tints, or stone colours<a1_0/>. The style in France was initially a <a4_0>Parisian<a4_0/> style, <b7_0>the Goût grec<b7_0/> ("Greek style"), not a court style; when Louis XVI acceded to the throne in 1774, <a2_0><b8_0>Marie Antoinette<a2_0/>,<b8_0/> his fashion-loving Queen, brought the "Louis XVI" style to court.
